newsitem.title: GERMANY: Canadian anti-whaling activist held in Germany.
newsitem.headline: Canadian anti-whaling activist held in Germany.

text.p: Authorities in the north German port of Bremerhaven have detained Canadian anti-whaling activist Paul Watson, wanted by Norway for trying to sink a whaling ship in 1992, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

Norway issued an international arrest warrant for Watson after he was sentenced to 120 days in jail in 1994 for opening the flood valves of the whaling ship in port, causing around $60,000 of damage. He failed to turn up for his sentence.

The high court in the city of Bremen will now have to decide whether Watson, 46, should be placed on remand pending an extradition request from Norway, a spokesman for the Bremen prosecutors' office said.

Watson is the head of a militant anti-whaling group called Sea Shepherd. He was one of the founders of the environmental group Greenpeace but left 20 years ago because it was not aggressive enough in its anti-whaling campaigns, Greenpeace's German headquarters in Hamburg said.
